name: 程聖倫
objective: This course will focuse on the application of principles of linear modeling in the context of linear regression analysis to exploring questions about mediated (i.e., indirect) and moderated (i.e., interaction) effects. We will spend part of the course talking about partitioning effects into direct and indirect components and how to quantify and test hypotheses about indirect effects, part talking about estimating, testing, and probing interactions in linear models, and part integrating moderation and mediation as “conditional process analysis” by discussing and how to conceptualize and test the contingencies of a mechanism. Computer applications will focus on R using off-the-shelf code and the PROCESS macro available through www.processmacro.org and documented in the text for the course. It is assumed that you have taken a course in multiple regression and have done well or are otherwise comfortable with the principles of multiple regression analysis. No knowledge of matrix algebra is required or assumed.
schedule:
week 1-2: Oview of the course and a gentle introduction to R

week 3: Overview and review of regression concepts

week 4-6: Statistical mediation analysis

week 7-8: Moderation analysis

week 9: Mid-term

week 10: Moderation analysis

week 11-12: Condtional process analysis I

week 13-14: Statistical mediation and moderation analysis II

week 15-16: Advanced topics in conditional process analysis

week 17: That’s a lot to process! Pitfalls of popular path models

week 18: Final
materials:
Course materials will be prepared by the instructor.

Optional:

Hayes, A. F. (2022). Introduction to mediation, moderation, and conditional process analysis: A regression-based approach (3rd ed.). The Guilford Press.
